etymologies: mid 16th century: from French frise, from medieval Latin frisium, variant of frigium, from Latin Phrygium (opus) ‘(work) of Phrygia’

definitions: a broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling

examples.text: the horsemen of the Parthenon frieze
the coastline is a frieze of cliffs

shortDefinitions: broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration

definitions: a horizontal paper strip mounted on a wall to give an effect similar to that of a sculpted or painted frieze

examples.text: a wallpaper frieze with chickens on it

shortDefinitions: horizontal paper strip mounted on wall

definitions: the part of an entablature between the architrave and the cornice.
shortDefinitions: part of entablature between architrave and cornice

etymologies: late Middle English: from French frise, from medieval Latin frisia, ‘Frisian wool’

definitions: heavy, coarse woollen cloth with a nap, usually on one side only.
shortDefinitions: heavy, coarse woollen cloth with nap
